idCitation.resTitle: Tight Oil and Shale Gas Plays in the U.S.

dataIdInfo.idPurp: This data was created for the purpose of identifying and providing information on shale plays in the United States.

Consts.useLimit: None (public use). Users are advised to thoroughly review the metadata to understand the appropriate use and limitations of the data. These data and related graphics, if available, are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such.The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The U.S. Energy Information Administration gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: General areas for shale plays in the U.S. Source: EIA based on Enverus DrillingInfo Inc., the U.S. Geological Survey, publicly available peer-reviewed research papers, academic theses, and publications of State Geological Agencies. Updated September 2019 with changes to Delaware play boundary.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: U.S. Energy Information Administration, Enverus DrillingInfo Inc., the U.S. Geological Survey

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Large-scale geologic depressions, often hundreds of miles across, which may contain oil and natural gas resources.
Fine-grained low permeability siliciclastic sedimentary rocks, in some areas interbedded with minor carbonate layers.

A set of discovered, undiscovered or possible natural gas accumulations that exhibit similar geological characteristics. Shale plays are located within basins, which are large-scale geologic depressions, often hundreds of miles across, which also may contain other oil and natural gas resources.
The area of the shale play in square miles.
Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The area of the shale play in square kilometers.

dataLineage.statement: EIA based on Enverus DrillingInfo Inc., the U.S. Geological Survey, publicly available peer-reviewed research papers, academic theses, and publications of State Geological Agencies. Updated September 2019 with changes to Delaware play boundary.

prcStep.stepDesc: To define play boundaries EIA uses an integrated approach based on analysis of major geological structures and tectonic features (regional faults and folds etc.), contoured elevation of the top of a formation (structure), contoured formation thickness (isopach), countered values of reservoir properties (porosity, density, TOC, thermal maturity, clay content, carbonate content etc.), and well-level hydrocarbon production.
